channel.title: [Visual Basic 2008] Server Code Generator 0.8 [/Source Download]
channel.description:
This is the source download for my tool; it has been created in Visual Basic 2008 and i am giving it out since this board started and since im re-making it in Visual Basic 2010 as it seems naicer. This Version hasn't been packaged into Folders and crap. Its pretty fucked thats why im remaking it ;) But it still gives an idea of a program that can be editted to be used for other shit. Also you may check the source code to learn some shit for your own application.
Download Link: [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?0j41jedojz4]MediaFire[/url] or download the attachment version. Originial Topic: [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,436212.0.html]http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,436212.0.html[/url]
[b]There is no point in leeching this, if you are dont bother downloading. Why? cause i didnt give you the packaged version and this one looks like all random shit.[/b]

item.title: [Visual Basic 2008] Server Code Generator 0.8 [/Source Download]
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:10, topic:340305”][quote author=pure2ownage link=topic=436669.msg3217408#msg3217408 date=1274820175]

I got a book on it a while back but i put it down because i started doing java and VB. May be it’s time i picked it up again!

As Pure said, if you know Java and VB, it will come very easily.

@TOPIC - Eeh, very simple thing for me, but this will help out alot of people.

not everybody is pro? O_o
[/quote]

I’m not saying its a pro thing if something is easy. I’m just saying, this peice in general, can be easy. All you have to do, is get a few different peices of code, and make a void built around it, to put in a few strings/ints from textbox’s. I know, its a little more complicated than that makes it sound, but you get what im saying.[/quote]
i do some people don’t.

Read full topic

item.title: [Visual Basic 2008] Server Code Generator 0.8 [/Source Download]
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:3, topic:340305”]“im re-coding it in Visual Basic 2010” How ironic. Surely you should be recoding it in something better… You’ll later realize the terrible syntax of the language, and how little functionality you have when it comes to the core.

[quote author=sp11k3t3ht3rd link=topic=436669.msg3215173#msg3215173 date=1274619568]
I’m making a command generator in Visual Basic 2008/2010 Express Edition but isn’t the code pretty much the same between 2008 and 2010? Or are you talking about legit Visual Basic 2008? Like the one that costs money.
[/quote]Visual Basic 2008 and 2010 are the same thing, with the exception of the IDE. There is no different version of Visual Basic with the exception of the cross-over between native Win32 and .NET applications. Visual Studio 2010 was made to increase team development and allow the new .NET Framework 4, which in this community most would find extremely useless. Visual Basic 20XX doesn’t cost money either way. There is the Express Edition IDE and there is the Visual Studio, which is just an IDE for all in one with some heavy development features especially for teams, which does cost money. Nobody in this community would have the need to get it either way.[/quote]
i am going to redo it in c# later but i cba atm.

Read full topic

item.title: [Visual Basic 2008] Server Code Generator 0.8 [/Source Download]
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

“im re-coding it in Visual Basic 2010” How ironic. Surely you should be recoding it in something better… You’ll later realize the terrible syntax of the language, and how little functionality you have when it comes to the core.

[quote=“sp11k3t3ht3rd, post:2, topic:340305”]I’m making a command generator in Visual Basic 2008/2010 Express Edition but isn’t the code pretty much the same between 2008 and 2010? Or are you talking about legit Visual Basic 2008? Like the one that costs money.[/quote]Visual Basic 2008 and 2010 are the same thing, with the exception of the IDE. There is no different version of Visual Basic with the exception of the cross-over between native Win32 and .NET applications. Visual Studio 2010 was made to increase team development and allow the new .NET Framework 4, which in this community most would find extremely useless. Visual Basic 20XX doesn’t cost money either way. There is the Express Edition IDE and there is the Visual Studio, which is just an IDE for all in one with some heavy development features especially for teams, which does cost money. Nobody in this community would have the need to get it either way.

Read full topic
